articles.headline: Google Announces 2-for-1 Stock Split
articles.snippet: The search giant also reported first-quarter revenue that rose 24 percent and earnings that slightly beat analysts’ expectations.
articles.abstract: The search giant also reported first-quarter revenue that rose 24 percent and earnings that slightly beat analysts’ expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google is getting back on its game.

articles.headline: States Seek Curb on Patient Bills for Costly Drugs
articles.snippet: So-called specialty drugs for diseases like rheumatoid arthritis have a narrow use and high costs, leaving the most vulnerable patients with huge bills.
articles.abstract: So-called specialty drugs for diseases like rheumatoid arthritis have a narrow use and high costs, leaving the most vulnerable patients with huge bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hemophilia drug that saves 7-year-old William Addison from uncontrolled bleeding costs $100,000 a year. His family’s insurance pays virtually all of it.

articles.headline: North Korean Rocket Fails Moments After Liftoff
articles.snippet: Defying weeks of international warnings of more censure and sanctions, North Korea launched a rocket on Friday, but it broke up just after liftoff, Japan said.
articles.abstract: Defying weeks of international warnings of more censure and sanctions, North Korea launched a rocket on Friday, but it broke up just after liftoff, Japan said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea defied international warnings of censure and further isolation on Friday, launching a rocket that the United States and its allies called a provocative pretext for developing an intercontinental ballistic missile that might one day carry a nuclear warhead.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Consumer Bureau Declines to Resist Upfront Credit Card Fees
articles.snippet: The agency set up to protect consumers appears to be allowing high upfront fees for credit card issuers.
articles.abstract: The agency set up to protect consumers appears to be allowing high upfront fees for credit card issuers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one of the first tests of its willingness to show its muscle, the new agency created to protect consumers declined on Thursday to put up a fight.

articles.headline: In Cash Push, 2 Campaigns Likely to Reject Public Funds
articles.snippet: Fund-raising goals make it virtually certain that neither nominee will accept public funds or the spending limits that come with them.
articles.abstract: Fund-raising goals make it virtually certain that neither nominee will accept public funds or the spending limits that come with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big money in presidential politics is about to get a whole lot bigger.

articles.headline: Argentina Has Oil Firm in Its Sights
articles.snippet: The fate of YPF was thrown into doubt as reports that President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was preparing to nationalize the company drew a warning from Spain.
articles.abstract: The fate of YPF was thrown into doubt as reports that President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was preparing to nationalize the company drew a warning from Spain.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The fate of Argentina’s largest oil company, YPF, was thrown into doubt on Thursday as reports that President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was preparing to nationalize the company drew a warning from Spain that it would consider such a move a hostile action.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Emily Schmall

articles.headline: Hard Times Lift Greece’s Anti-Immigrant Fringe
articles.snippet: The gains by Golden Dawn show how the economic collapse has empowered fringe groups, a situation that some in Greece have compared to Weimar Germany.
articles.abstract: The gains by Golden Dawn show how the economic collapse has empowered fringe groups, a situation that some in Greece have compared to Weimar Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — On a recent morning in the upper-middle-class neighborhood of Papagou here, members of the Greek ultranationalist group Golden Dawn stood at an outdoor vegetable market campaigning for the coming national elections.
articles.byline: By RACHEL DONADIO and DIMITRIS BOUNIAS

articles.headline: Murder Aside, China Inquiry Puts Couple’s Wealth on Trial
articles.snippet: Gu Kailai, a lawyer, spent more than two decades turning the government posts of her husband, Bo Xilai, into lucrative business opportunities.
articles.abstract: Gu Kailai, a lawyer, spent more than two decades turning the government posts of her husband, Bo Xilai, into lucrative business opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — What began as a scandal involving the mysterious death of Neil Heywood, the British businessman whose body was found in November in a Chongqing hotel room, appears to be evolving into a broader investigation into the wealth of a politically powerful Chinese couple, Bo Xilai and his wife, Gu Kailai, and their financial interests.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Clouds on Solar’s Horizon
articles.snippet: The decision by BrightSource Energy to withdraw its initial public offering on Thursday highlights the difficulties facing the solar market. Despite a vast increase in installations, profits remain scarce.
articles.abstract: The decision by BrightSource Energy to withdraw its initial public offering on Thursday highlights the difficulties facing the solar market. Despite a vast increase in installations, profits remain scarce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late Wednesday night, BrightSource Energy, a start-up formed to build solar thermal power plants, was forced to make a humbling admission: Despite a year of hopes and efforts, it could not find the market it wanted for its stock. The company canceled its initial public offering of shares just hours before trading was to begin.

articles.headline: Rocket Failure May Be Test of North Korean Leader’s Power
articles.snippet: A spectacular failure to put a satellite into orbit raises the question, American officials said, of whether Kim Jong-un will attempt to recover by staging a larger provocation.
articles.abstract: A spectacular failure to put a satellite into orbit raises the question, American officials said, of whether Kim Jong-un will attempt to recover by staging a larger provocation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, the spectacular failure of a rocket meant to put a satellite into orbit was more than a $1 billion humiliation. It could be the first test of whether anyone will dare challenge his rule, and raises the question, American officials said, of whether he will be tempted to recover by staging a larger provocation.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger
